comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I do not think that's York Street for it's not wide enough. I can see tram wires in the distance. It shows Victoria Barracks on North Queen Street on my prewar map but the building in the background to the right is either York Street Mill or Gallaher's Tobacco Factory.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] So is that the Peoples Hall? The map I'm looking at (1931) doesn't have a T-junction at my proposed location.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It's a well known phenomonen; You read what you expect to read. That's why when you're comparing two texts to see if they're the same you should read them backwards - it removes all the context and lets you just compare the words.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Or is it the Sinclair Seaman's Church (Presb.)? The picture matches the ground plan on the map. Assuming the tower's been refurbished, it's not a bad match. Let's see what archiseek says.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Apparently the Sinclair Seaman's Church (Presb.) is not architecture.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: ...but I'm pretty sure that's not it anyway. For a start, it's on corporation square.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: My map doesn't show a T junction either. I wondered about Sinclair Seamen's Church but it's so different.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: From Irish Methodism in the twentieth century "THE NORTH BELFAST MISSION was founded in 1897 by the Rev. William Maguire. Its headquarters was the old Frederick Street Chapel. Later the New Connexion Chapel in York Street was acquired, and when remodelled, called the People's Hall, and this is now the headquarters of the Mission."

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] That's what I was thinking but the map isn't a great match with the buildings in the timber yard.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Methodist, I think.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: North Belfast Mission is Methodist.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] .The building work above must then have been part of the remodelling that took place from 1905. I've been told the OS 25" dates from 1910 so maybe that little house on the right was demolished to make way for the bigger building seen on map? This area seems to have been known as "Salem". Is it still called Salem?  meaning peaceful.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Along the lines of "they make a desert and call it peace"?

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: These must be some of the striking carters that joined with James Larkin in the 1907 Belfast Dock strike

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: This is the junction of Great George's Street and York Street as shown on the map posted above by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03]. In my 1902 map this building is shown as Salem Methodist Chapel (New Connexion). It was listed as "Salem Church - Rev Wm Maguire" in 1908 Street Directory. The York St Timber & Slate Yard was at 86-92 York Street and 59 Gt George's Street, owned by TS Dixon & Co - you can see Dixon's name under the arch.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: This same photograph also appears in "Images of Ireland - North Belfast" (compiled by Peggy Weir). Incorrectly labelled as 'coner of York Street and Frederick Street' it shows more of the photo - left and bottom - including the Gt George's Street gable of Dixon's Timber Yard with a large "OXO" advertisement - and posters!

comment._content: nmni.com/Home/online-collections/Item-Details.aspx?id=226... National Museum of NI has this too

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From Weekly Irish Times on Saturday, 3 August 1907:
BELFAST LABOUR DISPUTES ... [Tuesday 30 July] Matters were more lively in the city to-day owing to another outburst of activity on the part of the pickets. Vans were held up in different parts of the city, the most flagrant case being, perhaps, that which occurred in Great George's street. Two lorries proceeding from the Midland Railway Terminus to Messrs. David Allen and Sons' printing establishment in Corporation street were stopped and overturned, the contents of one being scattered over the street. Shortly afterwards a spring van was stopped and the goods removed, but on the arrival of police from Henry street Barracks they were replaced, and the van resumed its journey under escort. In Royal Avenue a number of vehicles were turned, and in the vicinity of Smithfield and the Great Northern Railway goods yard pickets were to be seen at every street corner.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I spotted this flyer the other day in a new batch of digitised items we've put online, and as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] mentioned above here's further evidence of a James Larkin connection with this Belfast Dock Strike.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
